title: Nabil Fekir’s former agent reveals who botched his Liverpool transfer
text:
Nabil Fekir was still at Lyon when Liverpool did a deal to bring him in for £50million (Picture: Getty)

Nabil Fekir’s injury history was just one of the reasons behind his failure to join Liverpool last summer, according to one of the men involved with the deal.

Fekir had been prolific for Lyon in the 2017/18 season, scoring 23 goals in 39 games in all competitions and helping the club to Champions League qualification by virtue of finishing third in Ligue 1.

The France international caught the attention of a number of clubs but Liverpool negotiated a £50million deal to bring him to Anfield – only for the deal to break down at the last minute.

‘Nabil was Liverpool’s priority. I worked for four months with the Liverpool representatives, with Jurgen Klopp, Jean-Michel Aulas [Lyon president], everything was ready,’ Fekir’s former agent Jean-Pierre Bernes told French TV station Canal+.

‘Nabil was already aware of his future contract, which would have seen him earn around [£40m] over five years.

‘And on the day that the contract was supposed to be signed, at Rambouillet, we saw a lawyer and Nabil’s brother-in-law arrive who said: ‘Stop everything, discussions have to start all over again.’

‘It was surreal. We thought that we were in a Walt Disney film.

‘[Fekir’s brother-in-law] all of a sudden acted like a player’s agent.

‘He wanted a commission, everyone knows, it is fashionable these days.

‘[Fekir] was on a cloud, he seemed to have transformed, he didn’t even greet the Liverpool representatives.

‘He arrived after the medical, everyone was looking at each other, the Liverpool representatives were wondering where they were. I was ashamed.’

Nabil Fekir ended up joining Real Betis this summer (Picture: Getty)

It was initially reported that a previous knee injury and the risk of it reoccurring put Liverpool off the player.

And while Bernes admitted that his knee played a role, he claims the club would have overlooked the issue if they had not had other doubts.

‘There were two elements,’ Bernes added.

‘The player’s medical was negative and the second element was that when you want to sign for a big club like Liverpool, you need a certain attitude.

‘When the Liverpool guys witnessed this [drama], they immediately…

‘Sometimes when a player has an injury, representatives can make an effort to make it work.’
